metadata.titleEn: Human activity parameters at Qilian Mountain Area (V1.0) (2018)
metadata.description: This data set includes 30 m farmland and bulidingland distribution products in Qilian Mountains in 2018. The product is based on Landsat-8/OLI data. In the production of farmland products, the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) is used, and the production rules are set by using the prior knowledge of crop phenology and planting types. In the production of buildingland products, the normalized NDVI is used by using the Landsat series data synthesized in summer. other indexs like NDBI, MNDWI and other data like DEM, lighting data are used together to set product production rules. The accuracy of the products of farmland andbuildingland in 2018 is 90.05% and 90.97% respectively, based on the high-definition image of Google Earth and field survey data.

background: The increased information on time dimension of time series HJ-1/CCD data improves the classification accuracy for most of the land cover types including water bodies, urban areas, forestlands, and croplands; consequently, the overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient have 10% and 0.1 improvements respectively. The advantage of HJ-1/CCD data in land cover/use classification makes it a reference for new remote sensing satellite or sensor development. Overall, a new land cover/use classification method using HJ-1/CCD data based on time series analysis is developed and this method does improve the classification accuracy compared with the method using single remote sensing data. In addition, the introducing of the very high spatial resolution data within Google Earth can also improve the sampling accuracy and lower the cost of data purchasing and field campaigns.
research objective: Therefore, by taking the spatiotemporal advantage of HJ-1/CCD data we propose a new method for finer resolution land cover mapping using time series HJ-1/CCD data, which can greatly improve the land cover mapping accuracy.
challenges: This method uses much more data and dramatically increases the computation loading; the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data lower its usability and increase the difficulty in its use.
methods: In this study, the advantages of HJ-1/CCD on spatial resolution and temporal frequency are fully taken to make a time series data with 30 m spatial resolution of experimental areas. The land cover classification method using time series HJ-1/CCD data includes six steps, which are detailed as follows: (1) Constructing the time series HJ-1/CCD data. In order to take advantages of HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping, the composite of experimental areas is made using multi-scenes of HJ-1/CCD images, and 12 composites corresponding to 12 months in 2010 are made, which are made up the time series images of the experimental areas yearly. (2) Data preprocessing. After the data are prepared, the data pre-processes including geometric correction, radiometric calibration and atmospheric correction need to be done to make a “perfect” time series HJ-1/CCD data composite. (3) NDVI calculating. Instead of time series of HJ-1/CCD data, time series of NDVI are used as the input of SVM for classification. (1) Sampling. The classifier used in this study is SVM, which needs a good sample set for training purpose. (2) SVM classification. Support Vector Machine (SVM) is a robotic learning method developed from statistics learning theory and optimization theory in the 1990s. (3) Post-classification. Some of the land cover types are very difficult to separate, so some extra work needs to be done to improve the classification accuracy.
dataset: The data are downloaded for free at websites of Satellite Environment Center, Ministry of Environmental Protection or China Center of Resources Satellite Data and Application. The HJ-1 satellite constellation consists of three satellites, named as HJ-1A, HJ-1B, and HJ-1C respectively. HJ-1A has two CCD cameras and one hyperspectral instrument onboard; HJ-1B has two CCD cameras and one infrared camera onboard; HJ-1C is a SAR satellite. For CCD cameras, their nominal spatial resolution is 30 m. HJ-1/CCDs have three visible bands (430–520 nm, 520–600 nm, and 630–690 nm) and one near-infrared band (760–900 nm).
findings: In our two study areas, the very high resolution remote sensing data within Google Earth are used to validate the land cover mapping results, which shows a very high mapping accuracy of 95.76% and 83.78% and a high Kappa coefficient of 0.9423 and 0.8165 in the Dahuofang area of Liaoning Province and the Heiquan area of Gansu Province respectively.

background: Land-cover datasets are crucial for research on eco-hydrological processes and earth system modeling. Remote sensing has become widely used as a macro-observing system for land-cover mapping, which can substitute for plant functional type (PFT) as the baseline. Several moderate to fine resolution global land-cover datasets, which are presented in detail in Table I, based on different satellite sensors are available from different research groups. These land-cover datasets listed in Table I have large variability for three reasons: 1) the data quality and properties are different; 2) there is no standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories; and 3) they are not consistent with the Earth System Model’s (ESM) requirements, because the concept of PFT, whose traits represent a combination of spectral relationships, and climatic, ecological, and theoretical assumptions, used in ESMs cannot be mapped directly using remote-sensing land-cover datasets. The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover.
research objective: In order to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling in the HRB, a comprehensive method for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution and more categories of crop/vegetation is developed by using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands.
challenges: The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover.
methods: The procedure for constructing time series of the HRB mosaics from HJ-1/CCD is introduced as follows and the details of the procedure can be found in [26]. Geometric correction: A mosaic of the HRB is made using Landsat/TM imagery. The mosaic of Landsat/TM is used as the base image and all HJ-1/CCD images are automatically corrected through the image-to-image registration method by [43]. Radiometric calibration: Converting the DN values of the HJ-1/CCD images to top of atmosphere (TOA) radiance with given calibration coefficients. Atmospheric correction: Removing the atmospheric effects of remote-sensing images to obtain the surface reflectance. This correction was achieved with a spatial extension method developed by [44]. After the preprocessing has been done, all the HJ-1/CCD images within 1 month are subset and mosaicked; consequently, 10 mosaics for 10 months in the HRB are made and time series of the HRB mosaics from HJ-1/CCD are constructed.
dataset: The HJ-1/CCD remote-sensing data used in this research were provided by the China Centre for Resources Satellite Data and Application (CRESDA, http://www.cresda.com). The Landsat TM/ETM+ data were downloaded from the USGS website (http://landsat.usgs.gov/). The MODIS data were downloaded from the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (http://ladsweb.nascom.nasa.gov/). The VHSR data were from Google Earth by Google Inc.
findings: A ground campaign was performed to evaluate the accuracy of crop classification and an overall accuracy of 84.09% for the crop classification was achieved.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how remote sensing data is utilized to improve land cover classification accuracy in eco-hydrological research?
Example.Answer: In eco-hydrological research, remote sensing data like HJ-1/CCD, Landsat, and MODIS are used to construct time series data for land cover classification. These datasets help improve accuracy by providing detailed temporal and spectral information that is crucial for distinguishing between various land cover types.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered when using optical remote sensing data for land-cover classification?
Example.Answer: A common challenge in using optical remote sensing data for land-cover classification is the high uncertainty between certain categories, such as cropland and grassland, particularly in dryland systems. This is due to the variability in the minimum threshold required for forest cover.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used to create a high-resolution land cover map using time series analysis?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used for creating a high-resolution land cover map is the HJ-1/CCD satellite data. This data provides time series images with a spatial resolution of 30 meters, which are used for land cover classification through various processing steps like geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction.

Definition.Question: What do 'spatiotemporal advantages' mean in the context of remote sensing data for land cover mapping?
Definition.Answer: The term 'spatiotemporal advantages' refers to the benefits of having both spatial resolution and temporal frequency in remote sensing data, which can enhance the accuracy of land cover mapping by providing continuous and detailed datasets over time.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'geometric and radiometric correction' in the preprocessing of remote sensing data?
Definition.Answer: 'Geometric and radiometric correction' in remote sensing data preprocessing involves modifying the raw data to correct distortions and inaccuracies. Geometric correction aligns the images with geographical coordinates, while radiometric correction adjusts the data to reflect true surface radiance by compensating for sensor and atmospheric effects.

Definition.Question: What does 'normalization indices' refer to in the context of remote sensing data analysis?
Definition.Answer: 'Normalization indices' in remote sensing data analysis refer to mathematical combinations of spectral bands, such as NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index), NDBI (Normalized Difference Built-up Index), and MNDWI (Modified Normalized Difference Water Index), used to enhance certain features and improve land cover classification.

Interpretation.Question: What data collection methods can be inferred as necessary for accurately mapping land cover types using time series satellite data?
Interpretation.Answer: Accurate land cover mapping using time series satellite data requires constructing a composite of images from multiple scenes, preprocessing for geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction, and utilizing indices like NDVI for classification. Very high spatial resolution data from sources like Google Earth can also improve sampling accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: How might the challenges in land-cover classification between cropland and grassland categories inform the design of data collection strategies?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges in distinguishing between cropland and grassland due to classification uncertainties suggest a need for enhanced data collection strategies that include multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data. This approach helps in accommodating the variability in data quality and resolving inconsistencies with Earth System Model requirements.

Interpretation.Question: What potential datasets or remote sensing technologies could be integrated to enhance the classification accuracy of land cover mapping in eco-hydrological models?
Interpretation.Answer: Potential datasets include HJ-1/CCD remote sensing data, Landsat TM/ETM+ data, MODIS data, and very high spatial resolution data from Google Earth. Integrating these datasets with advanced classifiers and leveraging their spatial and temporal resolution advantages can significantly enhance classification accuracy in eco-hydrological models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the increased computation loading in data collection methods for land cover mapping using time series analysis?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The method uses a large amount of data, which significantly increases the computation loading. Additionally, the not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of HJ-1/CCD data make it harder to use, thus increasing the complexity of data processing.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there high variability and uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: High variability and uncertainty arise due to differences in data quality and properties, the lack of a standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories, and the inconsistency with Earth System Model’s requirements. Additionally, optical imagery often struggles to differentiate between similar categories like cropland and grassland, and in dryland systems among shrub, grassland, and forest due to differing definitions of minimum forest cover thresholds.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of using time series HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping on the classification accuracy of remote sensing datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using time series HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping could significantly improve classification accuracy due to the increased information on the time dimension, leading to better identification of land cover types such as water bodies, urban areas, forestlands, and croplands. This method improves overall accuracy and the Kappa coefficient by 10% and 0.1, respectively, compared to using single remote sensing data.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might incorporating very high spatial resolution data from sources like Google Earth impact the validation and cost of land cover mapping datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating very high spatial resolution data from sources like Google Earth can improve the sampling accuracy and lower the cost of data purchasing and field campaigns, resulting in high mapping accuracy, as evidenced by the validation results showing a mapping accuracy of 95.76% and 83.78% in two study areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of developing new methods for land cover mapping using time series HJ-1/CCD data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to greatly improve the land cover mapping accuracy by leveraging the spatiotemporal advantages of HJ-1/CCD data, which includes enhancing classification accuracy for various land cover types and making it a reference for new remote sensing satellite or sensor development.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it beneficial to use very high spatial resolution data within Google Earth for land cover mapping validation?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using very high spatial resolution data within Google Earth can significantly improve the sampling accuracy and reduce the cost of data purchasing and field campaigns, thereby enhancing the overall effectiveness and efficiency of land cover mapping validation.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intention behind using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data for eco-hydrological and land-process modeling in the HRB?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling by developing a comprehensive method for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution and more categories of crop/vegetation, thus addressing the high uncertainty in land-cover classification between different categories.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in developing a high-accuracy land cover classification method using time series remote sensing data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps involved in developing a high-accuracy land cover classification method using time series remote sensing data include constructing the time series data using multi-scene composites, conducting geometric correction, performing radiometric calibration, applying atmospheric correction, calculating NDVI for input into classification algorithms like SVM, and conducting post-classification adjustments to enhance accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can remote sensing data from multiple sources be integrated to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling, remote sensing data from multiple sources can be integrated by constructing time series mosaics, performing geometric and radiometric calibration, and conducting atmospheric correction. This integration allows for mapping with fine spatial resolution and more categories of crop/vegetation using multiple classifiers and multisource data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in time series analysis enhance the accuracy of land cover classification using remote sensing data?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements in time series analysis, such as using HJ-1/CCD data, improve the classification accuracy for land cover types by providing more detailed temporal information, which enhances the overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient of classification results.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for improving the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling through land cover mapping methodologies?
Enablement.Answer: To improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling, a comprehensive method using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands is necessary, along with addressing uncertainties in classification, especially between cropland and grassland categories.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in using time series data for land cover classification?
Expectation.Answer: The challenges in using time series data for land cover classification include the increased computation load due to the large amount of data and the difficulties arising from not very good geometric and radiometric qualities of some satellite data, which lower its usability and increase the difficulty in its use.

Expectation.Question: Why is there a high uncertainty in land-cover classification between certain categories such as cropland and grassland?
Expectation.Answer: The high uncertainty in land-cover classification between categories like cropland and grassland is due to differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover and variations in data quality and properties, which affects the ability to classify continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories.

Expectation.Question: What are the potential advantages and disadvantages of using HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping?
Expectation.Answer: The potential advantages of using HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping include improved classification accuracy due to its spatial resolution and temporal frequency, which can be enhanced by developing a time series analysis. However, disadvantages include challenges related to the data's geometric and radiometric qualities, which may complicate its usability.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using time series HJ-1/CCD data in improving land cover classification accuracy compared to single remote sensing datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of time series HJ-1/CCD data significantly improves land cover classification accuracy due to its spatiotemporal advantage. It provides better classification of land cover types like water bodies, urban areas, forestlands, and croplands, resulting in a 10% increase in overall accuracy and a 0.1 improvement in the Kappa coefficient. However, it also introduces challenges such as increased computational load and the need for improved geometric and radiometric quality.

Judgmental.Question: What are the perceived challenges in classifying land cover using remotely sensed imagery, particularly in distinguishing between cropland and grassland?
Judgmental.Answer: The primary challenge in classifying land cover using remotely sensed imagery lies in the high uncertainty between categories like cropland and grassland, especially in dryland systems. This is due to variations in the minimum threshold required for forest cover and differences in the data quality and properties. Addressing these uncertainties requires better classification methods and the integration of multiple data sources.

Judgmental.Question: In your view, how crucial is the role of Google Earth's very high spatial resolution data in enhancing the accuracy and cost-effectiveness of land cover mapping?
Judgmental.Answer: Google Earth's very high spatial resolution data plays a crucial role in enhancing the accuracy of land cover mapping by providing precise validation data. It improves sampling accuracy and significantly reduces the cost of data purchasing and field campaigns. This capability allows for more accurate and cost-effective land cover mapping, especially when used alongside other remote sensing datasets.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced when using time series HJ-1/CCD data for land cover mapping.
Assertion.Answer: One of the main challenges is that using time series HJ-1/CCD data significantly increases computational load. Additionally, the geometric and radiometric qualities of the data are not optimal, which complicates its usability for accurate land cover mapping. Despite these challenges, the spatiotemporal advantages of HJ-1/CCD data can enhance mapping accuracy when compared to single remote sensing datasets.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why there is a high uncertainty in classifying cropland and grassland from optical remotely sensed imagery.
Assertion.Answer: The uncertainty in classifying cropland and grassland arises due to the variability in data quality and a lack of standard classification approaches. Moreover, differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover contribute to this uncertainty, particularly in dryland systems where shrub, grassland, and forest categories overlap.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential remote sensing datasets that could be integrated to improve eco-hydrological process modeling and discuss their respective contributions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include HJ-1/CCD data, Landsat TM/ETM+ data, MODIS data, and very high spatial resolution data from sources like Google Earth. Each dataset provides different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands, which can collectively enhance modeling by offering more detailed and varied land-cover information. These datasets can help address issues of classification uncertainty and improve overall modeling accuracy.
